subject: Re: [junit] splitting this list
msgSnippet: I agree. There are those who seemingly are smart enough to subscribe to the mailing list, yet not wise enough to perform some simple search engine searching.
messageBody:
I agree. There are those who seemingly are smart enough to subscribe
to the mailing list, yet not wise enough to perform some simple search
engine searching.

The best manner of dealing with them that I have seen, is to gently
welcome them to the world of JUnit, suggest that they start by reading
the resources available at junit.org and that they then follow that up
with reading one of the fine books available at their local or
Internet book store. And it never hurts to mention ESR's Smart
Questions essay.

That does take a few minutes, but it's the nicest way to deal with
that sort of person that I've seen. This list is very friendly and
helpful and populated by some fine people, so the last thing we want
to do is to seem judgemental or rude. Products are judged by their
mailing list. Think of Perl, a scripting language that is many orders
of magnitude more difficult to learn than JUnit, but it's mailing
lists are reputed for their friendliness. We should be the same way.
Study how J.B. and some of the others deal with the beginner/unwise
questions that come through the list.

Oh, and remember back to when you were confused and asking questions.
I try to keep learning new things so I have no problem remembering
back to a day when I didn't "just know" the answer. You should see
some of the stupid questions that I've asked over at the Groovy
mailing list! But they are very kind and patient over there. We
are/should remain that way over here. :-)

Simon

--
www.simonpeter.com

On 9/21/05, David Jackman <david.jackman@...> wrote:
> Unfortunately, I think the people who send a question without looking in
> the FAQ or doing a simple Google search are also those people who would
> send the question to both the simple and advanced group in hopes of
> getting a faster response.
>
>
> ________________________________
>
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
> Bradley, Todd
> Sent: Wednesday, September 21, 2005 11:23 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] splitting this list
>
>
> Hi, I'd like to propose a controversial topic, which is to somehow split
> up the JUnit email list into two lists - one for beginners and one for
> intermediate-to-advanced users. I cherish the discussion on this list
> about meaty topics of unit testing and using and extending JUnit. There
> are some very smart people here!
>
> However, I frankly have reached the limit of my tolerance for stupid
> questions in this list. And by "stupid questions" I mean the opposite
> of Eric Raymond's "smart questions"
> (http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html). There seems to be
> no end to the steady stream of new members who sign on and immediately
> ask a question that's already answered in the JUnit FAQ, which every new
> member automatically receives. I know hitting the delete key 5 or 10
> times a day isn't a huge deal, so I guess it's just the principle of it
> all. I consider it rude for people to not have the courtesy to at least
> make an effort to help themselves.
>
> But I thought that rather than just unsubscribing from the list, I'd
> toss this message out to see if anyone else is in the same boat as me.
> There are supposedly over 6000 subscribers, which sure sounds like a big
> enough population to allow some specialization. Alternatively, if
> dividing the junit@yahoogroups.com list isn't likely to happen, does
> anyone know of a similar forum for "intermediate-to-advanced" users of
> JUnit with a better S/N ratio?
>
>
> Thanks for listening,
> Todd.
> ----
> Todd Bradley - Polycom, Inc.
> Test Lead, Proximo Projects
